stance_1: I am fond of hamburgers
stance_2: I choose meat based on cost
justification: The interviewee explicitly states that fondness for hamburgers is connected to cost: hamburgers are chosen in part because they fit the budget.

stance_1: I am fond of hamburgers
stance_2: I choose meat based on convenience
justification: The interviewee mentions choosing hamburgers because they are easy to get when eating out, connecting fondness for hamburgers with convenience.

stance_1: I am fond of hamburgers
stance_2: I choose meat based on nutrition
justification: While the main reasons for consuming hamburgers are cost and convenience, nutrition is also a consideration for meat choices generally, which may loosely support hamburger consumption.

stance_1: I buy rotisserie chicken for a good deal
stance_2: I choose meat based on cost
justification: The interviewee directly states that buying rotisserie chicken is motivated by getting a good deal, which is about cost.

stance_1: I buy rotisserie chicken for a good deal
stance_2: I choose meat based on convenience
justification: Buying rotisserie chicken is described as easy to get, connecting this behavior to convenience.

stance_1: I buy rotisserie chicken for a good deal
stance_2: I eat pork and chicken more than beef
justification: Frequent purchasing of rotisserie chicken for cost and convenience likely contributes to the higher consumption of chicken relative to beef.

stance_1: I choose meat based on cost

justification: The interviewee explicitly lists cost and convenience together as primary motivations for meat choice, indicating strong support between them.

stance_1: I choose meat based on cost

stance_1: I choose meat based on convenience

justification: Convenience and nutrition are both described as important and considered together in meat choices.

stance_1: I eat a variety of meats for nutrition
stance_2: I try to increase variety of meats eaten
justification: The interviewee explicitly connects increasing variety of meats eaten with nutritional motivation.

stance_1: I eat a variety of meats for nutrition

justification: Buffets are described as an opportunity to try a variety of meats for nutrition.

stance_1: I eat a variety of meats for nutrition

stance_1: I eat more meat at buffets

stance_1: I eat more meat at buffets

stance_1: I try to increase variety of meats eaten

stance_1: I socialize with people who prepare uncommon meats

stance_1: I eat pork and chicken more than beef
stance_2: I try to increase variety of meats eaten
justification: Eating pork and chicken more than beef suggests a lack of variety, in tension with the effort to increase variety.

stance_1: I eat pork and chicken more than beef
stance_2: I try to be open to trying new meats
justification: Favoring pork and chicken more than beef may indicate less openness to trying new meats, though the interviewee is working to change this.
